text.title: Measure the Distance to a Galaxy

head.s: Measure the Distance to a Galaxy

p.s: With the advent of internet access to scientific papers and research , plus some know-how of relativity , it is now remarkably easy to measure , with significant accuracy , the distance to spiral galaxies without using luminosity or red shift .

item.s: Find a clear digital photograph of the galaxy whose distance you wish to measure .
These are available on the NED or MAST DSS websites .

figure.rend: Measure the Distance to a Galaxy Step 1 Version 4.jpg

item.s: Save the photo as a negative and print it on a printer .
Although this can be done on a computer screen using Gimp .

figure.rend: Measure the Distance to a Galaxy Step 2 Version 4.jpg

item.s: Draw a line along the major axis of the galaxy .

figure.rend: Measure the Distance to a Galaxy Step 3 Version 4.jpg

item.s: The spiral galaxy will have spiral arms which will cross the line you have drawn at regular intervals .
Make a measure of the distance between these intervals .

You may use a ruler on a printed out photo and take an average , or use the measuring device in Gimp , or use MATLAB to extract the pixels along the major axis and apply a fast Fourier transform onto the extracted set of pixels if you are a geek .
Find the particular width in arc minutes of the photograph , which you will have used when selecting it from NED or MAST DSS .
The photo will also have its width given in pixels .
Or , if you have used a ruler , you can measure the width of the photo in inches or centimeters .
The purpose of this is to convert the measured interval length between spiral arms along the major axis of the galaxy into arc minutes .
It is important to measure , or determine , this interval in arc minutes .
And with a little algebra , this is very easy to do .
You do not have to be a geek to do it .

figure.rend: Measure the Distance to a Galaxy Step 4 Version 4.jpg

item.s: Find out how fast the galaxy is spinning .
Luckily , a vast number of galaxies have had their rotation speeds measured and these can be found online . Look for galactic rotation profiles or rotation curves and find one for your galaxy .
There is a way to find out how fast a galaxy is spinning using line widths , but that is not covered here .

figure.rend: Measure the Distance to a Galaxy Step 5 Version 4.jpg

item.s: When and if you find your galaxy 's rotation profile , it will be a graph of rotation velocity vs radial distance from the centre of the galaxy .
The velocity of rotation will flatten out to some maximum velocity , almost always given in Kilometers per second ( kps ) .
You will need to measure this maximum rotational velocity as best you can in kps .
Ignore every thing about dark matter ; it is completely irrelevant .
Multiply the interval measure in arc minutes times the maximum velocity of rotation measure in kps .

figure.rend: Measure the Distance to a Galaxy Step 6.jpg

item.s: That is the distance to the galaxy in parsecs .
If you multiply that distance by 3.26 , that is the distance in light years .

figure.rend: Measure the Distance to a Galaxy Step 7.jpg
